title: Interesting Etymologies Running List
text:
This is a running list of etymologies that I think are neat.
Temujin Genghis Khan was just a title; his real name was Temujin. Temujin is a Mongolic name that was probably borrowed from the Proto-Turkic *temÃ¼rÄi meaning â€œblacksmithâ€. The -ci suffix denotes a person who works with something, in this case *temÃ¼r, or iron. Modern Turkishâ€™s â€œdemirciâ€, also meaning â€œblacksmithâ€, is a descendent of this word and a cognate to Temujin. These names and their friends were and are still common throughout the region. For example, Timur (also known as Tamerlame), of the Timurid Empire, shares the same rootâ€”Timur, like Turkish demir, means iron.
Ordu is the Turkish word for â€œarmyâ€. It actually has an English cognate, â€œhordeâ€! Quite a few European languages seem to have picked this word up via contact with Central Asians. The most likely source appears to be Proto-Turkic, which makes sense given the role they played in Central Asian empires. But thereâ€™s another cognate to ordu thatâ€™s even more interesting: Urdu, the national language of Pakistan. The Mughal Empire of India established Persian as the official language of the empire, and the Hindustani dialect spoken in the military camps came to be referred to as â€œZaban-e-Urduâ€ in Persian, or â€œlanguage of the armyâ€, eventually being shortened to just â€œUrduâ€.
Rickshaws are small, hand-drawn passenger carts that were (and in some places, are) popular in Asia. It comes from the Japanese word äººåŠ›è»Š jinrikisha. But when it entered the English language, it actually already had a cognate, a word that came from the same root: wheel.
Five thousand years, a group called the Yamnaya used carts and wagons on the Ukrainian Steppe. This group is generally accepted to be the source of the Indo-European Languagesâ€”a language family encompassing languages as diverse as English, Persian, and Hindi. Their word for wheel was probably something like *kÊ·Ã©kÊ·los. This evolved over time to be something like *hwehwlÄ…, in Proto-Germanic, the most recent common ancestor of languages like German, English, and Norwegian. This eventually became hweÅl in Old English and wheel* today. That was journey that the word *kÊ·Ã©kÊ·los took westward to arrive in English as wheel. But how did it arrive in Japanese as jinrikishaw?
SoÄŸan
Chanterelle mushrooms

Temujin Genghis Khan was just a title; his real name was Temujin. Temujin is a Mongolic name that was probably borrowed from the Proto-Turkic *temÃ¼rÄi meaning â€œblacksmithâ€.
